Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They encounter choices where Christian ethics become more relevant
Story: I was halfway through my delivery route when my phone buzzed with a message from a customer. She sounded upset, asking why her package hadn’t arrived yet. I checked the tracking system and realized her order had been misplaced at the warehouse. My company expects me to handle these situations calmly and professionally, to reassure the customer and avoid blame. But as a Christian, I feel compelled to be honest, to admit the mistake and take responsibility, even if it means getting in trouble with my supervisor for not following the script. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between the company’s demand for polished, careful communication and my own conviction to speak the truth with humility. I could already imagine my manager’s disappointment if I confessed the error outright, but I also felt the weight of my faith urging me not to hide behind half-truths or excuses. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, caught between the expectations of my job and the values I hold most dear.
